title: Targeting Melanoma-Specific Tyrosinase: Cyclic Peptide Disrupts Actin Dynamics for Precision Apoptosis Induction
summary:
Melanoma is an aggressive and highly metastatic cancer that exhibits stubborn
resistance to conventional therapies, highlighting the need for novel
treatments. Existing therapeutic strategies often suffer from systemic
toxicity, poor efficacy and fast-gained drug resistance. In this study, we
designed a cyclic peptide system (c-RGDKYQ) that takes the advantage of the
overexpression of tyrosinase in melanoma cells to trigger enzyme-mediated
oxidation and self-assembly. The assembled peptide nanostructures can
selectively disrupt the actin cytoskeleton, impairing cancer cellular
functions, e.g., motility, adhesion, and proliferation, ultimately leading to
apoptosis. This approach does not rely on external drug payloads or complex
delivery mechanisms. c-RGDKYQ exhibits high selectivity for melanoma cells,
strongly suppressing tumor growth in a murine model with minimal systemic
toxicity. Our findings illuminate that, through targeting tyrosinase, c-RGDKYQ
may be an enzyme-responsive alternative to conventional treatments for
melanoma.
tldr: This paper presents a cyclic peptide (c-RGDKYQ) that targets melanoma by exploiting the overexpression of tyrosinase. Upon tyrosinase-mediated oxidation, the peptide self-assembles into nanostructures that disrupt the actin cytoskeleton, leading to apoptosis in melanoma cells both in vitro and in vivo with minimal systemic toxicity.
explanation: The study designs a cyclic peptide that selectively targets melanoma cells. The peptide (c-RGDKYQ) self-assembles into nanostructures upon oxidation by tyrosinase, an enzyme overexpressed in melanoma. These nanostructures disrupt the actin cytoskeleton, impairing cell motility, adhesion, and proliferation, ultimately inducing apoptosis. The research includes in vitro studies demonstrating selective cytotoxicity and disrupted actin filaments, as well as in vivo studies in a murine model showing significant tumor growth suppression with minimal toxicity. This approach avoids external drug payloads or complex delivery mechanisms.
interests_alignment: This paper aligns well with my research interests in peptide self-assembly and its application in biomedicine. The use of a cyclic peptide that self-assembles upon enzymatic activation is particularly interesting. Also the link to peptide sequence with the overall functionality is relevant. Although no machine learning is used in this project, the data on peptide sequences relating structure and function may be useful for future machine learning projects, making this applicable to my future research goals.

title: Open, Reproducible Calculation of Assembly Indices
summary:
We present assembly-theory, a Rust package for computing assembly indices of
covalently bonded molecular structures. This is a key complexity measure of
assembly theory, a recent theoretical framework quantifying selection across
diverse systems, most importantly chemistry. assembly-theory is designed for
researchers and practitioners alike, providing (i) extensible, high-performance
implementations of assembly index calculation algorithms, (ii) comprehensive
benchmarks against which current and future algorithmic improvements can be
tested, and (iii) Python bindings and RDKit-compatible data loaders to support
integration with existing computational pipelines.
tldr: The paper introduces 'assembly-theory', a Rust package for calculating assembly indices of covalently bonded molecules, offering a high-performance, extensible, and reproducible tool with Python bindings, designed to quantify selection in chemical systems. It addresses the computational challenges in assembly theory with cross platform support, memory safety and convenient parallelism.
explanation: This paper presents a software package, 'assembly-theory', implemented in Rust, for calculating assembly indices. Assembly theory is a framework useful in quantifying selection in chemical systems. The authors emphasize the package's high performance, extensibility, and reproducibility. Key features include implementation of assembly index calculation algorithms, comprehensive benchmarks, and Python/RDKit integration. The paper addresses the need for efficient and accessible tools in this domain, given that existing solutions may be approximate, closed-source, platform-dependent, or written in less common languages. The tests and benchmarks performed show that the Rust implementation outperforms other implementations (Go).
interests_alignment: While not directly focused on peptides, the paper aligns with my broader interest in computational tools for biomolecules and quantifying molecular structure. The concept of assembly indices, as a measure of molecular complexity and selection, could potentially be adapted or applied in the context of peptide self-assembly. The software's ability to integrate with existing computational pipelines (via Python bindings) and work with molecular structures also makes it potentially relevant to tools I use. Also, the topic of molecular assembly is very close to peptide self-assembly.
